overview: National Insurance contributions you can choose to pay when you have a gap in your National Insurance record
title: Voluntary National Insurance contributions

table.body:
You need 30 years of National Insurance contributions to get a full [State Pension](/state-pension#what-youll-get "basic State Pension") when you retire.

If you don't have 30 years of contributions you can pay voluntary contributions to fill or avoid gaps in your National Insurance record.

You may have gaps because:

- you're ill and and not working and don't get any benefits 
- you're unemployed and don't get any benefits 
- you live abroad and don't have to pay National Insurance 
- you're self employed making a profit under £5,595 and don't have to pay National Insurance

To get bereavement benefits you need to pay 39 years of National Insurance contributions for women and 44 years for men.

##Check your National Insurance record
You can [apply for a National Insurance statement](https://online.hmrc.gov.uk/shortforms/form/NIStatement?dept-name=&sub-dept-name=&location=40&origin=http://www.hmrc.gov.uk "apply for a National Insurance statement"){:rel="external"} from HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC) to check if your record has gaps.

The [State Pension profiler](http://www.direct.gov.uk/spptv5_en.dsb "state pension profiler"){:rel="external"} estimates your qualifying years and likely pension.

^When you get close to State Pension age HMRC sends you a [gap letter.](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/ni/volcontr/gapletter.htm "gap letter."){:rel="external"} This will tell you how much of a gap you have and how you can pay.^

##Decide if you want to pay voluntary contributions
You may want to pay voluntary contributions because:

- you're close to State Pension age and don't have 30 years of contributions 
- you have gaps in your National Insurance record and want to fill them 
- you know you won't be able to pay 30 years of contributions during your working life and want to avoid gaps (more years for bereavement benefits)

However, you have to be [eligible to pay voluntary contributions.](who-can-pay-voluntary-contributions "Who can pay voluntary contributions")

HMRC has more information on [deciding if you want to pay voluntary contributions.](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/ni/volcontr/toppingup.htm "Deciding if you want to pay voluntary contributions"){:rel="external"}



*[NICs]: National Insurance contributions
*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: Why pay voluntary contributions

table.body:
The table explains who is eligible to pay voluntary National Insurance contributions and which class to pay. 

Group | Eligible to pay voluntary contributions | Current rates 
- | - | -
Employed but earning under £107 a week and not eligible for [National Insurance credits](/boost-state-pension "national insurance credits") | Yes | Class 3: £13.25 a week
Self employed with profits under £5,595 and a ‘Small Earnings Certificate’ | Yes | Class 2: £2.65 a week 
[People living abroad](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/ni/volcontr/abroad.htm "people living abroad"){:rel="external"} - employed, self employed, unemployed immediately before leaving the UK | Only if at some point you've lived in the UK continuously for 3 years or paid 3 years worth of contributions | Class 2: £2.65 a week
People living abroad and not working in the country they moved to | Only if at some point you've lived in the UK continuously for 3 years or paid 3 years worth of contributions | Class 3: £13.25 a week 
Unemployed and not claiming benefits | Yes | Class 3: £13.25 a week
Married women who cancelled their [reduced rate election](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/ni/reducedrate/marriedwomen.htm "reduced rates"){:rel="external"} | Yes | Class 3: £13.25 a week
People eligible for [National Insurance credits](/boost-state-pension "national insurance credits") at the time of the gap | No | N/A
Married women or widows who chose to pay [reduced rates](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/ni/reducedrate/marriedwomen.htm "reduced rates"){:rel="external"} | No | N/A
People who reached State Pension age | You can only pay for the past 6 years | Class 3: £13.25 a week

^Voluntary National Insurance contributions paid from abroad don't cover your health insurance in the country you live.^

*[NICs]: National Insurance contributions
*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: Who can pay voluntary contributions

table.body:
##Rates for voluntary contributions

The current rates are:

- Class 2: £2.65 
- Class 3: £13.25 

These rates change every year.

You can pay voluntary contributions up to 6 years in arrears. The deadline is 5 April.

$E
**Example**  
You have until 5 April 2014 to make up gaps for the tax year 2007 to 2008. 
$E

$D

[Download 'National Insurance rates from 1999 to 2012' (PDF, 18KB)](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/stats/tax_structure/table-4.pdf "Download National Insurance rates from 1999 to 2012 (PDF, 18KB)"){:rel="external"}

$D

There are [exceptions to the 6 year rule](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/ni/volcontr/whentop-up.htm "exceptions to the 6 year rule"){:rel="external"}

##How to pay

You fill gaps by paying your Class 3 contributions as one lump sum. 

To avoid gaps you can set up regular payments for Class 2 or Class 3 over a longer period. You can do this by monthly direct debit or by paying quarterly bills from HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC).

If you're self employed or live abroad and choose to pay Class 2 you stop your payments when you make a profit of more than £5,595 a year or you return to the UK.


[Payment instructions](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/payinghmrc/class3nics.htm "payment instructions for voluntary contributions"){:rel="external"} and other ways of paying voluntary contributions are on the HMRC website.

There is also information about [paying voluntary National Insurance from abroad.](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/ni/volcontr/abroad.htm "information about paying voluntary National Insurance from abroad"){:rel="external"}


*[NICs]: National Insurance contributions
*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
